Undid revision 425909069 by [[Special:Contributions/Colejohnson66|Colejohnson66]] ([[User talk:Colejohnson66|talk]]) [[WP:OVERLINK]], no article on the girl exists (nor should it, as she had no notability outside of her suicide)
sometime in 2010 emo started to die out, and now poppy music like Katy Pary and Lady Gaga are taking the place of emo
Undid revision 417413029 by [[Special:Contributions/Bm superpig|Bm superpig]] ([[User talk:Bm superpig|talk]]) the article doesn't say anything about screamo experiencing mainstream success
rv. no, it originated from hardcore, as discussed in the article. "post-hardcore" was a term invented years later.

unwarranted. all samples relate specifically to the text & all have proper rationales. this article has 11...[[punk rock]], the only FA on a music genre, has 14. indicator that this is not an excessive amount for a substantial article.
Replace template per [[Wikipedia:Templates for discussion/Log/2011 February 18|TFD outcome]]; no change in content
Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/AbbaIkea2010|AbbaIkea2010]] ([[User talk:AbbaIkea2010|talk]]); No primary souces no reason of inclusion. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
Removing backlinks to De rigueur because "Unlinking backlinks to an article deleted following [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/De rigueur]]."; using [[WP:TW|TW]]

Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/ETFFAN123|ETFFAN123]] ([[User talk:ETFFAN123|talk]]); The shirts are mostly emo bands. Also i think thats what the sources say. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
Undid revision 406831720 by [[Special:Contributions/Omair00|Omair00]] ([[User talk:Omair00|talk]]) [[WP:OVERLINK]] (that would just go to a dictionary definition anyway)

Removed onesource banner; one source is cited frequently, though a variety of other sources are cited. I'll leave it to community discretion as to whether the page references should be compressed into one
/* Origins: 1980s */ use piped link; band's name was "Lunchmeat" during the time in question
Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/NewWaveKid|NewWaveKid]] ([[User talk:NewWaveKid|talk]]); No sources back up that assertion. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
making the dating more precise to illustrate Emo's mainstream break which was clearly in 2002 and the end of its era around the present time (2010)
Reverted to revision 402840427 by Sabrebd; Rvt unexplained changes. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/Corydor13|Corydor13]] ([[User talk:Corydor13|talk]]) identified as [[WP:VAND|vandalism]] to last revision by Xqbot. ([[WP:TW|TW]])

rv. so-called "emo pop" is not mentioned in the source and logically cannot be a stylistic origin, as it is a derivative or fusion style. there's no indication of who wrote the allmusic article, & citations belong in the body, not the lead.
Using Allmusic to improve the introduction to the article

Undid revision 401877357 by [[Special:Contributions/Tetraedycal|Tetraedycal]] ([[User talk:Tetraedycal|talk]]) "rock" is more general & contextualizes the topic for the reader. emo originated from hardcore punk but now has little in common w/ it.
it's a style of punk music, there must've been a mix-up somewhere
[[:en:WP:CLEANER|WikiCleaner]] 0.99 - Repairing link to disambiguation page - [[WP:DPL|(You can help)]] - [[Diary (album)]]
Bot: 5 external links adapted for allmusic.com, 5 migrated to template usage
Disambiguated: [[Clarity (album)]] → [[Clarity (Jimmy Eat World album)]], [[The Middle]] → [[The Middle (song)]] using [[tools:~dispenser/view/Dab_solver|Dab solver]]

rv. no reason given for this, no discussion on talk page. style originated in US & has had most of its activity/history there. very little notable emo-related activity elsewhere except what's discussed in the article re: UK & Mexico controversies.

Undid revision 397842651 by [[Special:Contributions/Gunmetal Angel|Gunmetal Angel]] ([[User talk:Gunmetal Angel|talk]]) this image has been previously added & rejected. some explanation at [[User talk:IllaZilla#Emo]]
/* Fashion and stereotype */ adding-in a picture, remove if it feels out of place.
rv completely [[WP:SOURCES|unreliable source]] (someone's personal wordpress blog)
Undid revision 394114067 by [[Special:Contributions/DriveMySol|DriveMySol]] ([[User talk:DriveMySol|talk]]) POV; no source indicating that it has somehow magically become unpopular
Date maintenance tags and general fixes: build X1
rv. see my reponse on my talk page. cartoonish fan illustrations are not encyclopedic material, and [[WP:OTHERCRAP|"but this other stuff..."]] arguments aren't relevant.
/* Fashion and stereotype */ And if you don't agree, feel free to remove all representative images of subculture: like [[Punk]]; [[metalhead]], etc. Why you are stuck on emo ?
/* Fashion and stereotype */ I think that the fact that the words are represented in image doesn't harm at all; it is even beneficial. A image is worth thousand words.

Undid revision 393617662 by [[Special:Contributions/Spatulli|Spatulli]] ([[User talk:Spatulli|talk]]) no, it isn't. the only thing in the text represented in the pic is a hair fringe. anyone can slap a pic here and say "this is what emo looks like".
The accurate definition of how an emo looks like is detailed in the paragraph and represented in the pic

rv. as you can imagine, we get any number of people posting random myspace-style pics on here claiming "this is what an emo kid looks like". there is no indication that these are typical of "emo" style, and claiming that they are is [[WP:NOR|OR]].
what is the meaning of this image? is someone just trying to get their face on Wikipedia? "old fashioned emo". ha!
rv. there is no indication to support that this is a "representation of a typical emo appearance". we don't typically accept people's sketches for these sorts of things.

Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contributions/I Will Conquer All 69|I Will Conquer All 69]] to version by Special Cases. False positive? [[User:ClueBot/FalsePositives|Report it]]. Thanks, [[User:ClueBot|ClueBot]]. (2928) (Bot)
/* Underground popularity: mid 1990s */ on consideration i can concede that this one isn't essential. if forced to cut one, this would be the one i'd choose

rv. the claim that this is "abuse" is unfounded. all these songs/artists/albums are specifically referenced in the sources as exemplars of the genre. discussion about the use of these files is ongoing (see the linked discussion on the talk page)
/* Underground popularity: mid 1990s */ no reason why we need to here "El Scorcho".
/* Underground popularity: mid 1990s */ no source for notability or why we need to hear a lifetime song
/* Underground popularity: mid 1990s */ we don't need to hear a single song to understand this concept
/* Independent success: late 1990s and early 2000s */ no sources, no discussion on this song at all
/* Mainstream popularity: 2000s */ non-free media abuse. we don't need to hear the files to understand the concept that they charted. that is all that is said about these songs in the article/refs
Undid revision 390721786 by [[Special:Contributions/Hole in my sock|Hole in my sock]] ([[User talk:Hole in my sock|talk]]) incorrect use of [[pull quote]]
/* Fashion and stereotype */ removed link to non-existent wiki
wow every POV statement is referenced by one book...tag with {{One source}} article as per [[Wikipedia:UNDUE]]..and removed {{Refimprove|section|date=May 2009}}

restoring citations to file captions, since one editor's primary rationale for the removal is that these songs are not specifically referred to in the sources as exemplars of the style. they are, which is why they were chosen in the first place.

rv. there is no consensus for the removal of these samples. every song and/or artist & their musical style is sourced in the article. the samples were chosen based on their analysis in the sources & their significance to the genre due to chart histor
Undid revision 388700634 by ([[User talk:IllaZilla|talk]]) per [[Wikipedia:Media copyright questions#excessive amounts of Fair-use Audio Files at Emo|MCQ thread]]

rv. bullshit. did you even READ the article? not only are some of the songs specifically referenced, every single artist's musical/lyrical style is specifically referenced. the samples serve to illustrate that style, which is impossible to do w/ text
None of these music samples are referenced in the article, total fail of [[WP:NFCC]] #8

minor change of link to magazine
the last edit was correct - but I like them around both

rv. (A) sources say "emotional", not "emotive". (B) IDOFEB, this is not the place to dump your rejected AFC submissions. if it was deemed inappropriate for its own article, it's not appropriate here either. full of [[WP:NOR|OR]] & poor sources.

Citations: [Pu177]Tweaked: url. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself! [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]].

rv. we don't need to name the specific acts here in the lead, as the number of artists referred to as "emo" in the last 10 years or so are quite numerous. the mentions (& refs) belong in the article body, not the lead.

rv. "later" does not relate to origins. the style originated from hardcore punk & indie rock, as discussed in the article body. pop-punk associations came way later, thus are not part of the "origins"

partial rv. source in the article uses the phrasing "broke into the mainstream". "emerged" is worse wording...it was around for a long time before hitting the charts. same thing for "more aggressive"
rv. "confessional-based"? bad grammar. screamo is not a [[fusion genre]], it is a [[subgenre]]

rv POV "widely", incorrect link "2000s decade". leave as-is
/* Criticism and controversy */general / misc. fixes using [[Project:AutoWikiBrowser|AWB]]
[[WP:UNDO|Undid]] revision 308025138 by [[Special:Contributions/Mineralboy|Mineralboy]] ([[User talk:Mineralboy|talk]]) not supported by the source cited. POV
emocore isn't a subgenre, it's the original term that later truncated to "emo". post-hardcore isn't an emo fusion genre, either. it's a subgenre of hardcore.
[[WP:UNDO|Undid]] revision 307728971 by [[Special:Contributions/Pop Punker|Pop Punker]] ([[User talk:Pop Punker|talk]]) POV
/* Fashion and stereotype */ oh geez. I am so, so sorry...
/* Fashion and stereotype */ sense sense sense
Whoever wrote this has clearly never taken a composition class.
[[WP:UNDO|Undid]] revision 306023170 by [[Special:Contributions/Palio10|Palio10]] ([[User talk:Palio10|talk]]) no evidence that post-hardcore is a subgenre of emo
[[WP:RBK|Reverted]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/Cheney666|Cheney666]] ([[User talk:Cheney666|talk]]) to last version by Cojoco
for this statement, greenwald notes that the genre has been *widely* criticized for this (not just by him). hence the attribution to greenwald is in the next sentence, before his specific criticisms.
/* Fashion and stereotype */ avoid weasel words, and clarify that this is still part of the stereotype
avoid weasel words - and i can't help thinking [[WP:UNDUE]] weight is given to a single source (it's also unclear how the criticisms are different to most pop music?)
true, but the text describes not only an androcentric (male-centered) view, but a tendency to rob women of agency & occasional anti-women sentiments, which are traits of misogyny.
/* Misogyny */ Not necessarily the same thing.
